explanations.A: Factors of 18 are the numbers which will go into 18. So 1, 2, 3, 6, 9 and 18 are all factors of 18 whereas 36 is a multiple of 18.
explanations.B: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 18. 6 is a factor of 18 as it fits into 18 exactly 3 times.
explanations.C: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 18. 9 is a factor of 18 as it fits into 18 exactly 2 times.
explanations.D: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 18. 18 is a factor of 18 as it fits into itself exactly.

explanations.A: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 12. 4 is a factor of 12 as it fits into 12 exactly 3 times.
explanations.B: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 12. 6 is a factor of 12 as it fits into 12 exactly 2 times.
explanations.C: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a factor of 12. 12 is a factor of 12 as it fits into itself exactly.
explanations.D: Factors of 12 are the numbers which will go into 12. So 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 12 are all factors of 12, whereas 24 is a multiple of 12.

explanations.A: Not quite! Remember a factor of a number is another number that divides into it exactly, leaving no remainder. Have you checked both Tom and Katie's numbers?
explanations.B: Not quite! Remember a factor of a number is another number that divides into it exactly, leaving no remainder. Have you checked both Tom and Katie's numbers?
explanations.C: Factors of (or numbers that go into) 12 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 12. Both Tom and Katie's numbers appear in this list; therefore, they are both correct.
explanations.D: Be careful! At least one of those numbers is a factor of 12. Remember a factor of a number is another number that divides into it exactly, leaving no remainder. Use this to check Tom and Katie's numbers again.

explanations.A: Factors of (or numbers that go into) 6 are 1, 2, 3, and 6. Only Jo is correct because in saying that 1 and 6 are two of the factors of 6, she hasn't described them as the only factors.
explanations.B: Not quite! 2 and 3 are factors of 6 but they are not the ONLY factors of 6. Remember a factor of a number is another number that divides into it exactly, leaving no remainder.
explanations.C: Be careful! Have a look again at the question, they cannot both be correct.
explanations.D: Not quite! Remember a factor of a number is another number that divides into it exactly, leaving no remainder. Using this, at least one of Jo and Paul is correct.

explanations.A: Not quite! Take another look at the question. 1 cannot be the answer as 2, 4 and 8 are NOT factors of 1.
explanations.B: Factors of (or numbers that go into) 8 are 1, 2, 4, 8. These are also factors of Answers C and D, but these answers have additional factors, whereas 1, 2, 4, 8 are the only factors of 8.
explanations.C: Good try! But, you want to select the number that ONLY has 1, 2, 4 and 8 as factors. 16 has an additional factor of 16.
explanations.D: Good try! But, you want to select the number that ONLY has 1, 2, 4 and 8 as factors. 64 also has 16, 32 and 64 as factors.

explanations.A: Be careful! 3, 9, and 18 are all multiples of 3 but they are not all factors of 3. Remember a factor of a number is a number that will fit into it exactly so that there is no remainder.
explanations.B: Almost! 2 out of the 3 numbers listed are factors of 9 but one isn't. Remember a factor of a number is a number that will fit into it exactly so that there is no remainder.
explanations.C: Factors are numbers that divide exactly into another number. 18 is listed as being a factor of the answer. Of the options given, it will only go into answer C which is 18.
explanations.D: Be careful! Not all of these numbers are factors of 27. Remember a factor of a number is a number that will fit into it exactly so that there is no remainder.

explanations.A: Not quite! The numbers shaded are all multiples of 2 but they are not the only multiples of 2 in the grid. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are the only multiples of that number?
explanations.B: The shaded numbers are 4, 8, 12, 16, 20... These go up in 4s so the grid shows the 4 times tables or multiples of 4.
explanations.C: Be careful! Some of the numbers shaded are multiples of 8, like 32, but they are not all multiples of 8, such as 28. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are all multiples of that number?
explanations.D: Be careful! Some of the numbers shaded are multiples of 12, like 24, but they are not all multiples of 12, such as 28. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are all multiples of that number?

explanations.A: The shaded numbers are 9, 18, 27, 36, 45... These go up in 9s so the grid shows the 9 times tables or multiples of 9.
explanations.B: Not quite! The numbers shaded are all multiples of 3 but they are not the only multiples of 3 in the grid. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are the only multiples of that number?
explanations.C: Be careful! Some of the numbers shaded are multiples of 18, like 36, but they are not all multiples of 18, such as 27. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are all multiples of that number?
explanations.D: Be careful! Some of the numbers shaded are multiples of 6, like 36, but they are not all multiples of 6, such as 27. Can you find the number where the ones shaded are all multiples of that number?

explanations.A: A multiple of 34 is the result of multiplying 34 by a whole number (so, in effect, the 34 times table). The number 17 does not fit this description.
explanations.B: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 34, 34 is a multiple of 34 as 34 ✕ 1 = 34.
explanations.C: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 34, 102 is a multiple of 34 as 34 ✕ 3 = 102.
explanations.D: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 34, 238 is a multiple of 34 as 34 ✕ 7 = 34.

explanations.A: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 21, 189 is a multiple of 21 as 21 ✕ 9 = 189.
explanations.B: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 21, 84 is a multiple of 21 as 21 ✕ 4 = 84.
explanations.C: Not quite! Take another look at the question. You are being asked to select a number that is NOT a multiple of 21, 21 is a multiple of 21 as 21 ✕ 1 = 21.
explanations.D: A multiple of 21 is the result of multiplying 21 by a whole number (so, in effect, the 21 times table). The number 7 does not fit this description.
